Editor's Note — This special supplement of the old home town paper is designed to assist in the staging of the 20th annual Winter Party in Vancouver. We appreciate the help we have been given. Many back home who read this in the World-Spectator will wish that they, too, could join the folks at the winter get-together.

This shot is one we prize especially. Major A. E. Christie and the late Fred Whitchelo are snapped at the picnic. Fred will be missed by all and many future meetings. Major Christie is ill in Victoria at present, and many friends wish him an early recovery.

Webster Widness, past president and past secretary, has given the editor all kinds of help in preparing this special supplement. Webster was the first printer's devil in the old "Spectator" office, and has been a friend of the printers ever since. Webster this year is on the reception committee, and the prize committee.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2 "YEARS 1883 to 1887 ONLY"

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

   Summer of 1883.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

MY FATHER LEARNED ABOUT THE WEST FROM HIS BROTHER FRANKLIN WILSON WHO HAD WORKED ON A SURVEY PARTY SOME YEARS EARLIER.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Understand they thought my parents were somewhat rash.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train via Chicago, St Paul, Emerson, Winnipeg, Moosomin, stage to Stony Creek. At Stony Creek, we were met by Uncle Robert Carruthers and taken to his place four or five miles north of what is now Rocanville. Our party consisted of my mother (Clarinda Widess) and her sister Mrs John Arnold, my brother Walter Wesley Widess (one year old) and three of the Arnold children, Sarah Jane, Walter and Minnie.

My Uncle John Arnold and my father reached Moosomin a few days after we arrived, along with the settlers' effects including cows and oxen etc.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). My earliest recollection would be the crossing of Stony Creek, no doubt because of the trouble getting over and the confusion on meeting Uncle Robert Carruthers. The next thing I remember was the building of Uncle John Arnold's house, and I can still smell those logs as the bark was peeled off them too, of course, the Indians began coming around. Our house was built after Uncle John's, and I remember well the Indians flattening their noses on the windows and peering in. Then quite often, they would file examine everything on the walls, take the guns down from the racks (all muzzle-loaders) put them back and file out again without saying a word. But they seldom left completely empty handed, even though my mother was badly scared half the time. By the time the rebellion was over, she was all for giving the country back to the Indians. However, we were never very much molested, and the family stuck it out until the harvest was taken off in 1887. The Arnolds remained there for the balance of their lives.

We then moved into the town of Moosomin after five years complete failure at the farming venture. My father was heart broken and died soon after.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the Harris House in Moosomin.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? S.W.¼ Sec 28, Twp 17, Rge 31, West 1st P.M.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

During this period (1883-1887) I was living with my parents on the farm.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Understand they thought my parents were somewhat rash.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family.

13. What mode of transportation did you use? Train via Chicago to St. Paul, then by stagecoach to Blythville. As story goes, we were met by Uncle Robert Curtiss and taken to a place four or five miles outside Midgley. I was about nine years old at the time.

My Uncle John Arnold and his wife Mrs. John Arnold children, Sarah Jane, Walter Wesley, and Minnie. John Arnold and his family resided in Moosomin a few days after we arrived. Along with the settlement effects including fences, etc., on its way westward, the Indians had been living in the area for many years.

Meeting Uncle Robert Curtiss and I can still recall those days. The Indians were friendly and welcoming. We were treated as guests and often they would be invited into our homes for dinner. They would bring us fresh meat and fish from the river.

The Arnold family remained close-knit until the death of my father in 1947. My mother remarried and moved to Regina where she died in 1965.

Letter writing to relatives in Ontario was common practice for quite a number of years, and in some cases has been kept up ever since, especially in the exchange of Christmas messages.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Nothing outstanding that I can think of, unless you have in mind such things as making our own tallow candles, prairie fires hundreds of miles in length, the use oxen, sickles, scythes and even flailles. All of these, I remember very clearly. Long hard winters, blizzards, cyclones. The quilting bees, dances, picnics. The first Rocanville picnic was held June 23, 1884, on the south bank of the Qu'Appelle valley just west of our place. The buffalo had gone but their skulls and horns were plentiful everywhere. Whole skeletons were becoming scarce but skulls and horns were common. Other game of all sorts were easily had for food purposes. In those early days, the Northern Lights were quite startling at times. You could actually hear them swishing past. We made our own Christmas trees by covering small trees with cotton batting and they were ornamental too.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes, mostly on foot or on ponies. For a time, I walked alone five miles to school and five miles back home again each afternoon. When the whole family went visiting, ox drawn sleighs and wagons were used, depending on the seasons of the year.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your mind? What would you have liked to record? Nothing outstanding that I can think of, except that I have in mind such things as making our own tallow candles, prairie fires hundreds of miles in length, the use of oxen, stories, bortles and even blizzards, cyclones. All of these I remember very clearly. Louis had winters, blizzards, cyclones. The first Rockville Plow was held June 27th, 1896. We built our own homes without the help of others. We made our own Christmas trees by covering small trees with cotton batting and they were ornamental too.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
For a few years after mid-summer 1883 our trading was divided between Fort Ellice twenty miles east and Moosomin twenty-five miles south.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
We moved to the town of Moosomin in 1887. Wheat was only worth 25¢ so it was left in the granary on the farm and sold in 1888 F.O.B. the granary for 92¢ per bushel.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
I would say not more than half a dozen times a year, possibly not that often, maybe only two or three times a year.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
Not at all in our time.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.
There was some mail-order buying from catalogues, but not much. I only remember seeing the catalogues around. We brought food supplies with us from Ontario, and at the beginning these were replenished by ordering through relatives back there. As far as I can recall, these consisted chiefly of Maple sugar and syrup, apples by the barrel, dried fruits of several varieties, and, no doubt there were many other staples. Hudson's Bay trading posts were still the most important shopping centers at the time we entered the N.W.T. It was a toss-up between Moosomin and Fort Ellice, but of course all the shipments from the east had to come by train to Moosomin, and anyway we eventually moved there.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
I had no choice. I grew up with it. But, my father and mother fully expected, when they left Ontario, to make a fortune and retire within a few years. Whatever gave them that idea is still a mystery to me.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving? Yes, plenty of them. Chief reason was, they had lost all the capital they had brought with them. Seed wheat cost them $2.50 or more per bushel, and when they had none for sale, it was only $2.54. Live stock was at the same rate. My father sold his original homestead (one plot) for either $285.00 or $385.00. I don't remember which. It was quite well improved, many times that amount had been spent on it, and five years of back-breaking labour.

40. The most noticeable changes during the past seventy years are that the hills are smaller, the valleys are not so deep and the trees in many cases have died a natural death. On the other hand many places where there were no trees at all 70 years ago are now heavily wooded. The Qu'Appelle River has swelled to nothing but a trickle, whereas during our time on the farm (1883-7) there was a board nailed to a tree on the riverbank telling us that a boat had come that far and turned back on such and such a date. I believe Walter Arnold, now residing at West Summerland B.C., could give you the exact wording on that board, and possibly the name of the boat too.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? (See Item 23, Questionnaire 2 covering the period 1883-1887)

I was at the Auction Sale of Beckton Brothers' stock in the market square at Moosomin in the late 90's, when Miss Tax, Mund X and Enogene were sold under the hammer for $2000.00 each, an unheard of price up to that time. That same afternoon, they presented their veterinarian Dr. Murison with that famous stud "Jas Philips", and to their trainer, a negro, they gave a most valuable black stallion. To Doctor Rutledge, their family physician, they presented a beautiful span of carriage horses with all the trappings complete. Many other presentations were made and it was a gala day for Moosomin. They must have realized quite a tidy sum of money, but even at that, their stock ranch at Cannington Manor was a total failure. "Jas Philips" remained in the district around the east end of the Moose Mountains for the rest of his life, and the improved quality of light weight horses was quite noticeable for many miles in every direction, for many years after the ranch closed up. The negro trainer took the valuable black stallion across the border into the U.S., and nothing more was ever heard of him.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Applicable to this period 1887-1905, the only travelling we did was by train up and down the main line of the C.P.R. to hockey matches and ball games. These games drew large crowds in those days, and quite frequently special trains (brought all the way from Brandon) were used to add a little encouragement for our home teams when away from home.

Once a year too, during the school holidays, all but the bread winners went down to camp at Fish Lake in the Moose Mountains. Before I was fifteen I built a good sized sailing boat in Moosomin, and hauled it 65 miles overland on wagon trucks, to launch it in Fish Lake. Each winter it was left in charge a man who lived all year round at the east end of the lake, and he finally fell heir to it. It was a good staunch vessel with a six inch keel from end to end. The oxen days were over when we left the farm, so by this time we were driving horses. And horseback riding was our chief means of travelling. I think the horses enjoyed it just as much as we did. Once, I rode a broncho 90 miles in less than 25 hours travelling time, and never put him off the walk.

The flour mill is no more, and whereas, at one time there were five grain elevators today there are only two. At one early day there were six hotels, today only one which is an amalgamation of two of the earliest, the Groover and the Queens. In 1887 there wasn't a tree in the town, whereas today one can hardly see it for the heavy growth of trees.

The little lake that was between the C.P.R. Station and the race track had dried up completely. I did hear they had drained it, but actually it had practically disappeared surrounding Moosomin, very little has been done to drain the sloughs and square off the fields since I left there in 1903, but in the rural district surrounding Moosomin, very little has been done to improve the marl lines, and even in the New England States, the same thing applies.

So, I suppose we can't complain.
